title: Considerations when picking a socket recv buffsize
body:
What are the benefits and drawbacks of choosing a buffsize that is larger (or smaller) than needed when working with sockets?

Consider my specific case as an example, I am using UNIX stream sockets in python to implement basic IPC for an app I am working on. There is one "server" process, and many "client" processes. The client processes connect to the server process's socket and send it commands. The server process receives those commands and executes them. The protocol they use is very simple, and the only notable rule is that each command must end with a semicolon.

The clients can send as many or as few commands as they'd like in each message (even a partial command, where the rest of the command and the accompanying semicolon are included in a future message). The server processes and stores messages in a queue until it receives a semicolon, then it saves the completed command to a queue.

The point of describing my simple example is to illustrate that in terms of information transfer, the buffsize argument passed to socket.recv() is completely irrelevant. i.e. I can call socket.recv(1) or socket.recv(1024) and the program's behavior doesn't change.

In situations like this, where the buffsize has no role in the overall execution of the underlying application, what is a good way to choose this value? What are some important things to consider when making this decision?

title: How should I implement a rust constructor compiled to wasm that will allow for javascript destructuring?
body:
I'm using rust-wasm, wasm-bindgen, to create a javascript wrapper for a rust library.

I have a rust constructor currently defined like

#[wasm_bindgen(js_class = Dater)]
impl DaterWrapper {
    #[wasm_bindgen(constructor)]
    pub fn new(
        dts: Option<String>,
        code: Option<String>,
        raw: Option<Vec<u8>>,
        qb64b: Option<Vec<u8>>,
        qb64: Option<String>,
        qb2: Option<Vec<u8>>,
    ) -> Result<DaterWrapper> {
        let dater = Dater::new(
            dts.as_deref(),
            code.as_deref(),
            raw.as_deref(),
            qb64b.as_deref(),
            qb64.as_deref(),
            qb2.as_deref(),
        )
        .as_js()?;
        Ok(DaterWrapper(dater))

It generates a js type constructor:

constructor(dts?: string, code?: string, raw?: Uint8Array, qb64b?: Uint8Array, qb64?: string, qb2?: Uint8Array);

Which doesn't allow for javascript destructuring. I'd like to used javascript destructuring to support named parameters in construction like new Dater({dts: now_datetime}).

Ignoring for the moment the poor design choice of allowing a constructor that can be constructed with different combinations of all optional parameters, is there any way to support destructuring (or a pattern) that makes this easy to do via wasm-bindgen? It seems like a common enough pattern that I'd rather not write js code to wrap the wrapper if there's an easier way to do it from Rust or ideally some kind of macro.

Any recommendations are welcome !

const headerItem = document.querySelectorAll(".header__item")
const headerSwitch = document.querySelector(".header-switch")
const headerSwitchCircle = document.querySelector(".header-switch__circle")
const hamburger = document.querySelector(".hamburger")
const nav = document.querySelector(".header__nav")
const cards = document.querySelector(".hero__container")
const meLink = document.querySelector(".me__link")
const albumContainer = document.querySelector(".album__container")
const albumButtonLeft = document.querySelector(".album__arrow_left")
const albumButtonRight = document.querySelector(".album__arrow_right")
const albumImages = document.querySelectorAll(".album__img")


function headerItems(){
headerItem.forEach(item => { 
    item.addEventListener("click", () => {
        document.querySelector(".header__item_active").classList.remove("header__item_active")
        item.classList.add("header__item_active")
    })
}) 
}

function toggleMode(){
headerSwitch.addEventListener("click", () => {
    headerSwitch.classList.toggle("header-switch_active")
    headerSwitchCircle.classList.toggle("header-switch__circle_active")
    document.body.classList.toggle("dark")
})
}


function toggleHeader(){
    hamburger.addEventListener("click", () => {
        hamburger.children[0].classList.toggle("hamburger__line_one")
        hamburger.children[1].classList.toggle("hamburger__line_two")
        hamburger.children[2].classList.toggle("hamburger__line_three")
        nav.classList.toggle("header__nav_active")
})
}

function toggleCards(){
    window.addEventListener("click", e => {
        cards.style.transform = e.target.innerHTML === "Home" ? `translateX(0)`:
            e.target.innerHTML === "About" ? `translateX(-100vw)`:
            e.target.innerHTML === "Projects" ? `translateX(-200vw)` : 0
})
}

function aboutMeLink(){
    meLink.addEventListener("click", () => {
        cards.style.transform = `translateX(-100vw)`
        document.querySelector(".header__item_active").classList.remove("header__item_active")
        headerItem[1].classList.add("header__item_active")
    })
}

function album(){
    let imgIndex = 0
    albumButtonLeft.addEventListener("click", changeImg)
    albumButtonRight.addEventListener("click", changeImg)
    function changeImg(e){
        imgIndex = e.target.classList.contains("album__arrow_right") ? imgIndex + 1 : imgIndex - 1
        imgIndex = imgIndex === albumImages.length ? imgIndex = 0 :
             imgIndex < 0 ? imgIndex = albumImages.length - 1 :
             imgIndex 
             albumContainer.style.transform = `translateX(calc(-${imgIndex} * 100%))`
    }
}

export function init(){
    headerItems()
    toggleMode()
    toggleHeader()
    toggleCards()
    aboutMeLink()
    album()
}

title: When converting C code structure to python, what is the best data type(s) to use?
body:
In 2019, I wrote a console application for Windows in C that allows the user to specify two elements from the periodic chart and responds with all possible combinations of the two elements. Since then, I have translated it into C++, C#, Java, and Delphi. Once I learn a new language, I convert Elements to ensure that the new language ‘sticks’ in my brain.

Now I want to convert Elements to Python. My grandson is learning Python and I would like to share the code with him, but I want to ensure that I make good use of the features that are unique to Python.

Here’s the first few lines of the periodic table data from my c++ version:

/*--- Instantiate 118 objects, one for each element ---*/
Elements AllElements[TOTAL_ELEMENTS] =
{
    Elements(  1, "H", "Hydrogen", 1.00794, "-1, 1"),
    Elements(  2, "He", "Helium", 4.002602, "0"),
    Elements(  3, "Li", "Lithium", 6.941, "1"),
    Elements(  4, "Be", "Beryllium", 9.012182, "2"),
    Elements(  5, "B", "Boron", 10.811, "3"),
    Elements(  6, "C", "Carbon", 12.0107, "-4, -3, -2, -1, 1, 2, 4"),

The values are atomic number, element symbol, element name, atomic weight, and the oxidation states possible for this element enclosed in a string. Elements was an array of structures in the original C code.

I could implement Elements as separate, parallel lists, which is appealing if I can implement oxidation state as a list of lists. Or I could use one of Python’s other data types, or create a class as I did with C++.

Do any Python developers out there have recommendations? I know there is always more than one way to do any type of programming, but what would you recommend as “best practices”? Thanks in advance for any suggestions.

I considered pairing the element name and element symbol as dictionaries, but wasn’t sure if that was a sensible use of that data type.

title: Is it possible to simplify the below git feature development workflow [ I want to release feature one by one to dev, stage, prod]
body:
Is it possible to simplify the workflow for feature development that I mentioned below? I don't want to utilize a release strategy instead of this; I want to deploy one feature at a time to the dev, stage, and production environments.

1. Create a Feature Branch:

git checkout development
git pull origin development
git checkout -b feature/asana-ticket-id/title-of-feature

2. Make Changes in Feature Branch:

Make your changes, commit, and push to the feature branch.

git add .
git commit -m "Description of changes"
git push origin feature/asana-ticket-id/title-of-feature

3. Deploy to Development:

git checkout development
git pull origin development
git checkout -b deploy/development/asana-ticket-id/feature-title
git merge --squash feature/asana-ticket-id/title-of-feature
git push origin deploy/development/asana-ticket-id/feature-title

4. Create a Pull Request:

Create a PR from deploy/development/asana-ticket-id/feature-title to development branch on your Git platform. Use the "Squash and Merge" option.

5. Deploy to Staging:

git checkout staging
git pull origin staging
git checkout -b deploy/staging/asana-ticket-id/feature-title
git merge --squash feature/asana-ticket-id/title-of-feature
git push origin deploy/staging/asana-ticket-id/feature-title

6. Create a Pull Request:

Create a PR from deploy/staging/asana-ticket-id/feature-title to staging branch. Use the "Squash and Merge" option.

7. Deploy to Production:

git checkout main
git pull origin main
git checkout -b deploy/main/asana-ticket-id/feature-title
git merge --squash feature/asana-ticket-id/title-of-feature
git push origin deploy/main/asana-ticket-id/feature-title

8. Create a Pull Request:

Create a PR from deploy/main/asana-ticket-id/feature-title to main branch. Use the "Squash and Merge" option.

title: Is it ethical to use <details> as a switch button?
body:
Recently I've started to use <details> and it made me realize it can be used in place of <button type="button"> components in stateless on/off switches without requiring to provide an onClick() callback (and therefore no dependency on javascript). Moreover because I use reactjs I have to introduce the state somewhere to control an on/off state for said button, which is kinda annoying if there are several of them in the same context. And if it's needed to be derived from state, then I can just derive the value of HTMLDetailsElement.open from it.
But before I've started to make a derivative component off <details> with <summary> styled the same as generic buttons in my project, is it a right thing to do, semantics-wise?
For me <summary> and a switchable component are perceived as different entities, but <details> is pretty permissive about its non-<summary> children (in fact it's the same permission as <div>). Doesn't help it's the only way I know of which allows for built-in switches without breaking overall semantics of the document, unlike the <input type="checkbox"> hack .

title: Should I create another table for recipe ingredients and its preparation steps?
body:
I use PostgreSQL. I have a table recipe, which contains recipe_id, title and description. But I also need to add the ingredients and method for each recipe. Each recipe has 5-6 ingredients and 5-6 method steps ordered by number (e.g. 1. prepare tomato, 2. put some garlic).

Which one of two approaches should I take?

  1. Create two separate tables ingredient and method. Inside of ingredient add column info and put each ingredient in a separate cortege.

    Then, for method add column step and put each step in a separate cortege.

    Finally, add recipe_id to ingredient and method to refer to the appropriate ingredient and step.

    INSERT INTO ingredients (ingredient_name, dosage, recipe_id)
VALUES
    ('Dried elderberries', '1 cup', 1),
    ('Water', '3 cups', 1),
    ('Cinnamon stick', '1', 1),
    ('Fresh ginger', '1 inch', 1);

    If we have 20+ recipes, the number of corteges will quickly become 100+ (5-10 ingredients for each recipe). I don't know if it's okay.

  2. In table method add all preparation steps for each recipe per cortege. And add all ingredients for each recipe per cortege. I could even put this as a column method directly in table recipe and not create separate tables at all.

    FindByPlate(plate string) (domain.Vehicle, error)
    Update(vehicle domain.Vehicle) (domain.Vehicle, error)

}

The question is, is this Idiomatic, or there is a better way of composing interfaces to achieve the same result?

title: Where should I put the sorting logic with Redux Toolkit?
body:
I'm currently keeping the logic for sorting a deck of cards in a separate util file and use it inside the slice reducer. Is that best practice for RTK, or should I create a separate selector? If yes, should it be on the same level as this slice? Should I decide to move it in a separate selector, would this leave my slice reducer empty?

import { createSlice, createAsyncThunk } from '@reduxjs/toolkit';
import { compareCards } from '../utils/customSort';

const initialState = {
  cards: [],
  status: 'idle',
  error: null
};

export const fetchCards = createAsyncThunk('cards/fetchCards', async () => {
  //fetches a shuffled deck of 52 cards
  const response = await fetch('https://firebase.com/cards.json');
  const data = await response.json();

  return data.cards;
});

const cardSlice = createSlice({
  name: 'cards',
  initialState,
  reducers: {
    sortCards(state) {
      //using it here
      state.cards = state.cards.sort(compareCards);
    }
  },
  extraReducers: (builder) => {
    builder
      .addCase(fetchCards.pending, (state) => {
        state.status = 'loading';
      })
      .addCase(fetchCards.fulfilled, (state, action) => {
        state.status = 'success';
        state.cards = action.payload;
      })
      .addCase(fetchCards.rejected, (state, action) => {
        state.status = 'failed';
        state.error = action.error.message;
      });
  },
});

export const { sortCards } = cardSlice.actions;
export default cardSlice.reducer;

title: Best Practices for Retrieving Selective Data from a Database in a RESTful API
body:
I am currently working on designing a RESTful API that interacts with an SQL database containing a 'Users' table. The example 'Users' table has fields such as AccountID, Username, Password, Firstname, Lastname, Email, Text, Setting1, Setting2, and Setting3.

In the services layer of my application, I have implemented getters and setters for Email, Text, Setting1, Setting2, and Setting3. Additionally, there are getters for Firstname and Lastname (but no setters).

The challenge I am facing is how to efficiently retrieve data from the database when the server code calling these services requires selective fields to perform various operations, while maintaining seperation of the business/services logic from the SQL statements (which exist in data gateway classes). For instance, one part of the code may need Firstname, Setting1, and Setting2, while another part may only need Lastname and Setting3.

I've considered two potential solutions:

  1. Sequential Field Queries: Query each field independently and in sequence. For example, first query for Firstname, then Setting1, and finally Setting2.

  2. Retrieve All Fields: Query all fields and retrieve the necessary data, ignoring the unused fields based on the requirements of the client code.

I am seeking guidance on the following:

  • Best Practices: How is this problem typically solved in the design of RESTful APIs?

  • Pros and Cons: What are the advantages and disadvantages of each method (sequential queries vs. retrieving all fields)?

  • Alternative Solutions: Are there alternative approaches or best practices for efficiently handling selective data retrieval in a scenario like this?

For a code example, the services/business logic functions look like this:

  getUserEmail(userId: number): string {
    // Implement logic to retrieve user email using the database gateway
  }

  setUserEmail(userId: number, email: string): void {
    // Implement logic to update user email using the database gateway
  }

  // Implement similar functions for other fields

  loginUser(username: string, password: string): boolean {
    // Implement logic to check if the provided username and password match a user, using the database gateway
  }

  getUserFirstname(userId: number): string {
    // Implement logic to retrieve user's firstname using the database gateway
  }

  getUserLastname(userId: number): string {
    // Implement logic to retrieve user's lastname using the database gateway
  }

The database gateway class looks like this:

interface UserTableGateway {
  // CRUD Operations
  createUser(user: User): void;
  readUser(userId: number): User | null;
  updateUser(user: User): void;
  deleteUser(userId: number): void;

  // Additional Query Operations
  getUserByEmail(email: string): User | null;
  getUserByUsername(username: string): User | null;
}

I appreciate any insights, experiences, or recommendations that you can provide. Thank you!

title: Handling Spring Security Oauth2 on a multiple services
body:
I have an auth service that uses oauth2 along with keycloak. Then i have 2 different services that both need to know which user is accessing them (directly). Right now i have these options:

  1. Auth service sets a jsession cookie by default. So it is stateful. I haven't found a way to make it fully stateless as it needs to save the code from oauth2. I will extract jwt token from it and set it as another cookie. Then i will set my other 2 services as stateless and call them using Bearer token. That works. I found this to be slower, as on every call my services will verify the token with keycloak. I also won't be able to make calls to auth service using Bearer token as it expects cookie-based session.

  2. I share my session via redis for every service that i need to. That way i can access all of my services (on same domain) without any need for setting my headers. I can also make internal calls to other services using that same cookie sent from client. And i found it to be much faster. However im not aware of consequences that may lead to.

  3. Make other services stateless, dont use security in them, route all my requests through gateway, gateway will convert my session cookie into jwt internally, services will simply decode jwt's as they are always signed by keycloak already since its routed through gateway.

I was wondering what is a common scenario for you guys? Is it a common practice to share sessions? And what scenario is preferable?

title: Architectural Best Practices for a Multi-Tenant Payment Service Platform with Regional Data Compliance
body:
I am in the process of designing a large system and I'm seeking advice on best practices for its architecture. The system is a payment service provider where we deal with individuals, merchants, partners and the system itself.

Individuals: like Paypal where you can raise invoices and get paid with multiple currencies. Individual can pay utilities, manage his wallet and send money to other individuals.

Merchants: something like Shopify where they can manage their stores, we use tenancy with multiple databases. The merchant can raise invoice, send payment link, create product, offer.. etc.

Partners: they can collect cash for merchants or deliver orders to customers.

System: the system itself where we manage the approval requests of individuals and merchants and all the system stuff.

When we started the project we were dealing with only one database since we had a very basic flow and we weren't focusing on a fully functional stores. So multi tenancy would be efficient for merchants. The app is a monolithic, and now we are considering separating the app into small modules Individuals, Merchants, Partners, System, Notifications.. etc. We might have more but these are the modules we current have.

Merchants can have Apps where they can consume our API and set redirect URL and be notified when a specific event happens with their merchant account like an invoice is paid, a new order is created.. etc. We have another micrcoservice which handles sending webhook events to merchants.

We also have a microservice to receive webhook events from the payment service providers.

Database architecture

we are considering separating the database into:

  • System database: where individuals basic info are stored, partners basic info, merchants basic info plus their store domains for tenancy.

  • Tenant database per merchant: every merchant will have their own database where products, invoices, orders, offers, employees, roles, permissions.. etc.

  • Partners database: one database to save all partners data.

  • Individuals database: one database to save all individuals data.

  • Notifications database: where we save the notifications for individuals, partners employees, system employees and merchant employees.

  • Payments database: where we are checkout details and online payment transactions for individuals, merchants and the system itself.

Is this database segmentation optimal for scalability and data isolation in a multi-tenant environment for merchants?

Frontend Structure

  • A dashboard for the partners, where they can collect cash and receive notifications regarding the new orders to deliver.

  • A dashboard for the system employees where we can manage everything.

  • A dashboard for individuals where they can manage their account and send invoices. Individuals can create merchant account and handle their stores, we have one dashboard for both individuals and merchants and every individual can be an employee in multiple merchant accounts with the same account.

  • A small project for checkouts and process collecting payments.

API Design

We are considering having one project for the API splitted into different modules like mentioned previously, with

api-individual.example.com // For individuals
api.example.com // For merchants
api-partner.example.com // For partners
api-system.example.com // For the system

We are going to use load balances, RDS's, Redis, Elastic-Search, Queues, S3 buckets.. and many more.

Compliance considerations

Since the payment industry is very regulated we need to keep this in mind, for the card holder details we need to save those data on soil in the country we are operating in. title: What is the correct way to create multi-step forms on the server side?
body:
I have an Application entity that includes other entities. In pseudo code that is not specific to a particular programming language, it would be described like this:

public class Application {
    public Client client = null;
    public Address address address = null;
    public House house house = null;
    public float price = 0;
    public boolean hasMortgage = false;
}

The validation of each entity is a separate step and is performed by the server, not the client

I see two options and want to know which one is used on real projects.

a) Each individual step:

1. User enters entity data
2. On the server the entity is validated in the controller of this entity
3. A record of the entity is created in the database
4. The id of the created record is returned to the user

When all steps are completed, the ApplicationController creates the Application entity, assigns the existing Address, House entities by their id and saves the Application entity record to the database.

b) At each individual step:

1. The user enters the entity data
2. On the server, the entity is validated in the controller of this entity
3. The user receives a response "Yes, you can go to the next step".

When all steps are passed, the ApplicationController creates the Application entity, creates the Address, House entities, assigns them to the Application entity, and only then saves records about all entities into the database.

title: faster plotting in matplotlib
body:
Please consider the following matplotlib code to plot a bunch of images. Is there a simple way to make it faster, or is multi-threading/processing the only way to go? I could live with lower resolution plots, if that makes it faster. Should I be considering other libraries PIL/Plotly/Seaborn? Will they make it faster?

import numpy as np
import matplotlib as mpl
mpl.use('Agg')
import matplotlib.style as mplstyle
mplstyle.use('fast')
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import time

style_dict = {
                'lines.linewidth':4,
                'lines.markersize':16,
                'lines.markeredgewidth':3,
                'legend.fontsize':24,
                'axes.titlesize':20,
                'xtick.labelsize':20,
                'ytick.labelsize':20,
                'axes.labelsize':28,
                'font.size':20 
             }


nsave = 30

t1 = time.time()

for isave in range(nsave):
    with mpl.rc_context(style_dict):
        data = np.random.random((64, 64))
        fig, (ax0,ax1) = plt.subplots(nrows=1,ncols=2,figsize=(16,8))
        cbar1 = ax0.pcolormesh(data)
        cbar2 = ax1.pcolormesh(data)
        ax0.set_aspect('equal')
        ax1.set_aspect('equal')
        fig.suptitle(f'Title for plot={isave}')
        plt.colorbar(cbar1,ax=ax0,fraction=0.046, pad=0.04)
        plt.colorbar(cbar2,ax=ax1,fraction=0.046, pad=0.04)
        # as suggested https://stackoverflow.com/a/66124971/13560598
        plt.minorticks_off()
        plt.tight_layout()
        plt.subplots_adjust(top=0.85)
        plt.savefig(f'plot{isave}.png')
        plt.close('all')
    
t2 = time.time()

t_elapsed = t2-t1
print(f'Elapsed time {t_elapsed}')

title: Including .h files of different modules in a upper level .h file is a good practise?
body:
Some months ago, I've designed a code in C for a flowmeter computer. For this reason, I'd used several libraries to make it modular, so if I wanted to make other versions or other projects using this libraries, it would be easy. The next image is the hierarchical scheme of all the libraries:

As you can see, it has all the .h files of every library, connected by 2 types of arrows, blacks or dotted reds. Black arrow means that the origin .h file uses the destination .h library functions in a direct way. A red dotted line means that the origin .h file doesn't use the destination .h library functions, but it uses at least a data type created on it.

So here comes my question. Is it correct to include .h files in other .h files in this way? For example, as you can see in the image, fm_lcd_flowmeter.h includes fmc.h, fm_lcd.h, fm_temp_stm32.h, fm_keypad.h, fm_calendar.h and fm_version.h (so fm_lcd_flowmeter.c includes only fm_lcd_flowmeter.h and no other libaries). Or is it more correct to include the .h files in the .c file that uses them?

In many cases, I've designed the libraries so the .h files define functions that can use data types defined in low level .h files, but is this an standard way to program in c using libraries? or at least is it correct?

I've several doubts about it after talking with some people about this C coding habit, who told me that it is not an standard way, it's not correct and it's not reusable, so I will be very grateful to hear some new opinions about this.

title: Why functions with arbitrary parametrs are defined as def func1(*args) and not func1(*params)?
body:
When we define a function what goes inside the parenthesis is called parameters and when we call the function and pass any values to the function, these values are called arguments.

Example:

def func1(a, b):
    pass

Here, a and b are called parameters.

When we call/invoke this function using func1(10, 20) here 10 and 20 are called arguments.

In case of arbitrary parameters as a general convention why the function is defined as

def func1(*args):
    pass

Shouldn't it be defined as below as general convention?

def func1(*params):
    pass

title: Optimise a program that outputs the earliest date
body:
I am attempting to solve Question 10 of Chapter 6 of the C programming: A modern approach book.

The question asks to write a program that determines the earliest date from a sequence of user-inputted dates. The user will enter 0/0/0 to indicate that no more dates will be entered. An example of the program output is also given by the book where the user input is highlighted in italic.

Enter a date (mm/dd/yy): 3/6/08

Enter a date (mm/dd/yy): 5/17/07

Enter a date (mm/dd/yy): 6/3/07

Enter a date (mm/dd/yy): 0/0/0

5/17/07 is the earliest date.

Below is my initial attempt which seems to produce the desired output:

#include <stdio.h>

// Below is a program that accepts any number of user-entered dates and returns the earliest date

// The program keeps track of a running variable for earliest month, day and year, against which each entry is compared

int main(void)
{

    int month, day, year;
    int earliest_month, earliest_day, earliest_year;

    // Initialisation

    earliest_month = 0;
    earliest_day = 0;
    earliest_year = 0;

    do
    {
        printf("Enter a date (mm/dd/yy): ");
        scanf("%d/%d/%d", &month, &day, &year);

        if (earliest_month == 0 && earliest_day == 0 && earliest_year == 0)
        {
            earliest_month = month;
            earliest_day = day;
            earliest_year = year;
        }

        // First compare the years
        if (year != 0 && year < earliest_year)
        {
            earliest_month = month;
            earliest_day = day;
            earliest_year = year;
        }
        else if (year == earliest_year)
        {
            // If years are equal, compare months
            if (month != 0 && month < earliest_month)
            {
                earliest_month = month;
                earliest_day = day;
            }
            else if (month == earliest_month)
            {
                // If years and months are the equal, compare days
                if (day != 0 && day < earliest_day)
                {
                    earliest_day = day;
                }
            }
        }

    } while (month != 0 || day != 0);

    printf("%d/%d/%.2d is the earliest date", earliest_month, earliest_day, earliest_year);

    return 0;
}

I now wish to get some feedback on this code and if possible, some recommendation on how to improve it. I already notice a double initialisation in my code precisely for the earliest month, day and year day variables (one outside the do and a second one inside the do statement). My idea was to have the earliest variables initially set to the first user output, but I still had to initialise them to 0 first (not sure whether that is required either but I also don't know how to make the program assign the first user input to these values).

Any feedback at all would be highly appreciated. Thanks in advance!

title: Efficient method for conducting a Cosmos DB health check in .NET with minimal Request Unit (RU) consumption
body:
I'm working on implementing a health check for my .NET application against an Azure Cosmos DB collection. I want to ensure that querying is functioning properly without incurring unnecessary costs in terms of Request Units (RUs).

I currently have a basic health check using the Cosmos DB SDK with a simple query:

var query = new QueryDefinition("SELECT GetCurrentDateTime ()");

try
{
    var iterator = container.GetItemQueryIterator<string>(query);

    while (iterator.HasMoreResults)
    {
        _ = await iterator.ReadNextAsync();
    }

    return new HealthCheckResult(HealthStatus.Healthy);
}
catch (Exception ex)
{
    return new HealthCheckResult(HealthStatus.Unhealthy, exception: ex);
}

title: Is It Good Practice to Directly Convert IQueryable to HashSet for Distinct Elements in C#?
body:
My questions are:

  1. Is it a good practice to directly convert an IQueryable to a HashSet<T> in this manner to ensure distinct elements?
  2. How does this approach impact performance, especially considering large datasets?
  3. Are there better alternatives or patterns for ensuring distinctness in the resulting dataset, particularly in Entity Framework and LINQ?

Any insights or suggestions for best practices in this scenario would be greatly appreciated.

public HashSet<MyDto> GetMyEntityRelations(
    int myEntityID,
    IEnumerable<MyEnumType> statusList,
    int contextId)
{
    var withAdditionalData = GetAdditionalDataQuery();

    var contextSpecificQuery = GetContextSpecificQuery(contextId, statusList.Select(x => (int)x));

    var query = (from relation in dbContext.Set<MyEntityRelation>()
                 join additional in withAdditionalData on relation.RelatedEntityID equals additional.EntityVersion.ID
                 join context in contextSpecificQuery on additional.EntityVersion.ID equals context.EntityID
                 where relation.MainEntityID == myEntityID
                 select new MyDto
                 {
                     EntityVersion = additional.EntityVersion,
                     EntityRelation = relation,
                     MyEntity = relation.RelatedEntity.Entity,
                     ContextEntity = context,
                     Translation = additional.UILanguageTranslation ?? additional.DefaultLanguageTranslation,
                 })
                 .TagWithCallSite();

    return new HashSet<MyDto>(query);
}

I attempted to optimize a database query in my C# application by directly converting an IQueryable result to a HashSet to ensure distinct elements. I expected this approach to efficiently remove any duplicate entries and handle large datasets without significant performance degradation.

I wasn't entirely sure if this was the most efficient way to ensure distinctness, considering Entity Framework's capabilities and best practices.

title: golang: pattern for handling message queues? Are functions anti-idiomatic?
body:
Me and my boss had a discussion today in how to implement services that works with messages coming in from event queues. We call these services processors. One of us argues for using several functions, while the other argues for fewer functions that do more things, according to idiomatic go. To make things more difficult, there's a healthy amount of async stuff happening and I'm new to async.

In essence, what the code must do is:

  • set up the project: config, logging and start the service up.
  • listening to message queues, potentially respond. Every time a message pops in, we may start to spin up a new goroutine.
  • process some of the data inside the message, potentially return it to the user.

I cannot just copy the code for legal reasons but will make pseudo code. One approach consists of making two functions, main() and do().

main sets up config, logger, and service. do listens to message queue. Because of NATS library, the code that handles the message is a callback function. It looks something like this:

sub, err := nats.Subscribe(topic, cbFunction)

This approach insists in making an anonymous function that peels the message for the field that we want to process, processes it if it's synchronous, and responds to the queue with a new message with a field containing this processed data.

# inside do()

sub, err := nc.Subscribe(topic, func(msg *nats.Msg) {
  // logs
  // checks data consistency
  // processes data
  // creates response with processed data inside
  // responds to queue with processed data
})

If it's async, then uses a channel to send data, and the part that processes it stays in it's own goroutine, listening to the channel.

# inside do()

go func() {
  for {
    select {
      // listens to channel and processes sent in data
      // handles errors if any
      // responds to queue
    }
  }
}()

sub, err := nc.Subscribe(topic, func(msg *nats.Msg) {
  // logs
  // checks data consistency
  // sends data to channel
})

There is another completely different approach, which is using newly created functions handleMessage(msg *nats.Msg) and process(data).

# outside do()

func handleMessage(msg *nats.Msg) {
  // logs
  // checks data consistency
  processedData, err := process(data)
  // creates response with processed data inside
  // responds to queue with processed data
}

func process(data) (processedData, error) {
  // processes data
  // returns processedData
}


# inside do()
sub, err := nc.Subscribe(topic, func(msg *nats.Msg) {
  handleMessage(msg)
})

if needs to be async, then process is invoked in do() and handleMessage doesn't call process directly, but rather uses channel. In turn, we have a second channel for returning data and potentially a third one for error. So:

# outside do()

func handleMessage(ctx, chIn, chOut, chErr, msg) {
  // logs
  // checks data consistency
  processedData, err := process(data)
  // handles errors or creates response with processed data inside
  // responds to queue with processed data
}

func process(ctx, chIn, chOut, chErr) (processedData, error) {
  // processes data
  // returns processedData
}


# inside do()
chIn := make(chan []byte)
chOut := make(chan []byte)
chErr := make(chan error)

go process(ctx, chIn, chOut, chErr)

sub, err := nc.Subscribe(topic, func(msg *nats.Msg) {
  go handleMessage(ctx, chIn, chOut, chErr, msg)
})

Right off the bat, which one is the best approach? Are there better ways of doing this?

Another big consideration: some of these processors are going to be an example for customers, who are also programmers. We're going to have examples in different programming languages. One side argue for all examples having the same structure. The other one for being idiomatic to each language. As a go dev, which example would you prefer and is clearer to grasp?

Other considerations that both side argue in their favour:

  • named functions: more simple, more testable, more reusable - processors would mostly differ in how they process the data.
  • anon functions: more simple, named function has too many channels, idiomatic go - fine for something like Python, but not go.

I expected to put up a case but he put a different one. Both have their merits and weaknesses, I guess. Which one would you prefer as go devs? Are we missing something? Should we be idiomatic or agnostic? Are three channels that much of a problem?

title: Should I create color cube linspace of size 256 or 257?
body:
I got color .cube file of size 33x33x33 and need to interpolate it to 256x256x256 LUT. The corrdinates of cells in the input table (by each axis) can be expressed by np.linspace(0, 1, 33) which returns values n/32: [0., 0.03125, 0.0625 ... 0.9375 , 0.96875, 1. ] or [0/32, 1/32, 2/32 ... 31/32, 32/32]

Now I need to generate coordinates of cells in the output table. Most examples on the Web suggest using linspace(0, 1, 256), but that generates odd numbers like these n/255: ([0. , 0.00392157, 0.00784314, 0.01176471, 0.01568627, 0.01960784, 0.02352941, 0.02745098, 0.03137255, 0.03529412, ... or [0/255, 1/255, 2/255, etc. Note that these values do not align with n/32 values, for example 0.03125 is close, but different from 0.03137255

I have better success with using np.linspace(0, 1, 257)[:-1] or with np.linspace(0, 1, 256, endpoint=False) which return more rounded n/256 values: [0. , 0.00390625, 0.0078125 , 0.01171875, 0.015625 , 0.01953125, 0.0234375 , 0.02734375, 0.03125 , 0.03515625, Here every 8-th element exactly matches element in 33 table: 8/256 == 1/32 == 0.03125, which simplifies interpolation calculations a lot: I can simply shift an index in 257 table by 3 to get index in 33 table.

Similar issue with octave: colorcube(256) gives odd numbers like 0.86667, 0.93333, but colorcube(257) gives much more rounded numbers like 0.81250, 0.93750 So, It looks like I should use an odd number when generating linspace or colorcube, but all examples, all articles on the Web use even numbers. What I am missing?

The difference between final LUT calculated using 256 vs 257 linspace is up to 1.5% in my case, so it may not be visible, but I am curious what is the right way to do that.

title: Should my SQL field names match my JSON fieldnames?
body:
I recently posted another question about decoding JSON in Swift below.

In Swift, how do I decode both lower case and pascal case JSON using Decodable protocol?

I was having issues with some JSON sources having camelCase fieldnames, while other JSON sources have PascalCase fieldnames. I concluded that I would enforce camelCase. So my JSON might look like...

{
    "fooBars": [
        {
            "fooBar": 1
        },
        {
            "fooBar": 2
        }
    ]
}

In SQL, however, I have been consistently using PascalCase when naming my tables and fields.

CREATE TABLE FooBars(
    FooBar int
)

So, if I want to use the FOR JSON clause in a SELECT statement, I need to alias my field names like this...

SELECT
    FooBar AS fooBar
FROM 
    FooBars
FOR 
    JSON AUTO, ROOT('fooBars')

Side Note: Interestingly enough, simply selecting the fieldname in camelCase form without an explicit alias works as well...

SELECT
   fooBar -- No alias required, even though the column is really called FooBar
FROM 
    FooBars
FOR 
    JSON AUTO, ROOT('fooBars')

Those queries will give me the JSON I am looking for in camelCase.

My question is, since this database will be dedicated for an iOS app I am developing, would it better for me to use camelCase field naming in the database as well and deviate from my standard SQL practice of PascalCase? Or is it acceptable to simply use my stored procedures to mold the data into the proper JSON form?

title: Global Secondary Indexes or manual replication in DynamoDB
body:
This is more an architectural question than other. I'm currently creating the data model part for a booking feature, and as a database I'm using Dynamo. Each user can book a spot in a SPA. I'm using the single table design and:

  • SPAs have PK SPA#spaID (SKs define other SPA's entities like employees, rooms etc.)
  • Users have PK USER#userID (SKs define other user entities, like profile, orders and so on)

Now the booking entity will have the usual booking data + spaId and userId which will need to be searchable with: I need to be able to get all bookings for a user and all bookings for a spa.

The solution of course would be to have the same booking being replicated on two PKs: SPA#spaId BOOKING#bookingID (as SK) and USER#ID BOOKING#bookingID (as SK)

I can see this would be achievable using Dynamo's Global Secondary Indexes having one single entity:

  • PK: SPA#spaID
  • SK: BOOKING#bookingID
  • GSIPK1: USER#userId
  • GSISK1: BOOKING#bookingID

This would mean that updating one single PK will then automatically update the Global Secondary Index replication automatically, if I understood correctly

But I'm not sure this is the right approach. On many single table design videos I saw architectures manually replicating the data, so updating first [PK SPA# SK BOOKING#] and then [PK USER# SK BOOKING#]

Is there any reason why I should follow the second path? Are there any limitations on the GSIs that I'm not seeing right now?

title: Converting MongoDB Query to manual operations in Java
body:
I have this method:

public void generateZonesFromLatLong(MongoCollection<Document> collection) {
        // Getting min and max latitude and longitude

        Document d = collection.aggregate(Arrays.asList(
                new Document("$group", new Document("_id", null)
                        .append("leftLongitude", new Document("$min", "$starterPoint.longitude"))
                        .append("rightLongitude", new Document("$max", "$starterPoint.longitude"))
                        .append("topLatitude", new Document("$max", "$starterPoint.latitude"))
                        .append("bottomLatitude", new Document("$min", "$starterPoint.latitude"))
                )
        )).first();

        // Assigning to variables
        double leftLon = d.getDouble("leftLongitude");
        double topLat = d.getDouble("topLatitude");
        double rightLon = d.getDouble("rightLongitude");
        double bottomLat = d.getDouble("bottomLatitude");

... other code

And i have this main class:

@SpringBootApplication
public class PredictiveServiceApplication {

    @Value("${spring.data.mongodb.host}")
    private String mongodbHost;

    @Value("${spring.data.mongodb.port}")
    private int mongodbPort;

    @Value("${spring.data.mongodb.database}")
    private String mongodbDatabase;

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        ConfigurableApplicationContext context = SpringApplication.run(PredictiveServiceApplication.class, args);
        PredictiveServiceApplication application = context.getBean(PredictiveServiceApplication.class);
        application.run();
        context.close();
    }

    public void run() {

        

        // Connection to db
        MongoClient mongoClient = MongoClients.create("mongodb://" + mongodbHost + ":" + mongodbPort);
        MongoDatabase database = mongoClient.getDatabase(mongodbDatabase);
        ServiceDB serviceDB = new ServiceDB();

       
        MongoCollection<Document> citizenRequestCollection = database.getCollection("citizenRequest");

        serviceDB.generateZonesFromLatLong(citizenRequestCollection);

This is pretty straight forward: I use mongo's queries to get specific values from the collection. But since i'm working on Springboot, and developing a Backend, i shouldn't have to manually take a collection.

For example, in this case, i shouldn't use getCollection with the document name, and then operating on the collection. In Spring, this becomes a simple getter in a controller, like this:

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/citizenRequests")
public class CitizenRequestController {

    @Autowired
    private CitizenRequestService citizenRequestService;

    @GetMapping
    public List<CitizenRequest> getAllCitizenRequests() {
        return citizenRequestService.getAllCitizenRequests();
    }
}

My question is: the query i did at the beginning on the collection, using mongo, was pretty brief and (as i know) was better on the performance side.

If i want to convert that query in java, i should cycle through the list and saving the minimum and maximum latitude and longitude. Something like this:

public void generateZonesFromLatLong() {

        List<CitizenRequest> citizenRequests = citizenRequestController.getAllCitizenRequests();

        double leftLon = 0;
        double topLat = 0;
        double rightLon = 0;
        double bottomLat = 0;

        for (CitizenRequest citizenRequest : citizenRequests) {
            double lat = citizenRequest.getStarterPoint().getLatitude();
            double lon = citizenRequest.getStarterPoint().getLongitude();

            if (lat < bottomLat){
                bottomLat = lat;
            }
            if (lat > topLat){
                topLat = lat;
            }
            if (lon < leftLon){
                leftLon = lon;
            }
            if (lon > rightLon){
                rightLon = lon;
            }
        };

So, my question is: what's better? Cycle throught it using a for cycle, or is there a better way to use directly the mongodb's queries?

title: Should i pass an object or a Func/Action to a method in C#
body:
There are any differences between passing a simple plain object, or a lambda function that return the same object and which option to chose in terms of performance/readibility?

Given an example class, i don't understand in which scenarios should i chose to make a method require a Func/Action paramether instead of just the object that it returns, when most of the times just a simple inline lambda function will be used.

public static class TestClass
{
    public static void someOperation<T>(Func<T> test) where T : notnull
    {
        var x = test.Invoke();
        
        Console.WriteLine(x.ToString());
    }
    public static void someOperation<T>(T test) where T : notnull
    {
        Console.WriteLine(test.ToString());
    }
    public static void someOperationOnString(Func<string> test)
    {
        string x = test.Invoke();

        Console.WriteLine(x);
    }
    public static void someOperationOnString(string test)
    {
        Console.WriteLine(test);
    }
}

TestClass.someOperation(() => "Hello, World!"); // Hello, World!
TestClass.someOperation("Hello, World!"); // Hello, World!
TestClass.someOperation(() => 1); // 1
TestClass.someOperation(() => new { test = "some test" }); // { test = some test }

TestClass.someOperationOnString(() => "my random string"); // my random string
TestClass.someOperationOnString("my random string"); // my random string

I know that the Func will be invoked after the method call, but basically in both case it will be invoked so there shouldn't be any differences in terms of performances. I also noticed that many libraries/frameworks uses the Func option, but i don't understand the advantages and when to choose one or the other. (e.g. Asp.net Core)

title: Best practices for creating Angular HTTP Interceptor in multiple libraries?
body:
Most of the literature for HTTP interceptors discusses creating a single HTTP interceptor for a single app.

I am creating multiple service-wrapper libraries for REST API calls, and each of these libraries would need its own HTTP Interceptor.

All these libraries will be used in multiple applications.

The applications themselves have no knowledge of any HTTP calls being made. Thus I am keen to avoid any "leaky" implementation where the applications start depending directly on one or more interceptor.

I would like to understand the best practices for such a situation:

a) should I declare the interceptor with multi-provider in each library's NgModule, and then import those library modules using importProvidersFrom in the main application as per this example

@NgModule({
  providers: [
    { provide: HTTP_INTERCEPTORS, useClass: NgProgressInterceptor, multi: true }
  ]
})
export class NgProgressHttpModule {
  static withConfig(config: NgProgressHttpConfig): ModuleWithProviders<NgProgressHttpModule> {
    return {
      ngModule: NgProgressHttpModule,
      providers: [
        { provide: NG_PROGRESS_HTTP_CONFIG, useValue: config }
      ]
    };
  }
}


---

in the application:

bootstrapApplication(AppComponent, {
  providers: [
    importProvidersFrom(BrowserModule, AppRoutingModule, NgProgressHttpModule, NgProgressRouterModule),
    provideAnimations(),
    provideHttpClient(withInterceptorsFromDi())
  ]
}).catch(err => console.error(err));

p.s. Seems like this was the option provided for standalone components, and for those, the new recommendation is provideHttpClient or

b) Should I provide a forRoot implementation in each library's NgModule and declare the interceptors as providers in the forRoot method? (e.g.) or another example

As per this explanation, it seems like using forRoot is the recommendation for providers which should be instantiated only once per application (i.e. Singletons); this is echoed here as well.

@NgModule({
    imports: [ConcreteAuthModule]
})
export class AuthenticationModule {
    static forRoot(config: AuthConfig): ModuleWithProviders {
        return {
            ngModule: AuthenticationModule,
            providers: [
                {
                    provide: AUTH_CONFIG,
                    useValue: config
                }, {
                    provide: HTTP_INTERCEPTORS,
                    useClass: BearerInterceptor,
                    multi: true
                }
            ]
        };
    }
}

--- 

in the App Modules:

imports: [
    BrowserModule,
    HttpClientModule,
    AuthenticationModule.forRoot({ /* config stuff */ })
  ],

However, I do not see this pattern followed in the Angular source code for HttpClientXsrfModule so I'm confused.

c) A good tip in this blog post clarifies that as per the Angular guide it is best to import the HttpClientModule only in the AppModule for each app, and shouldn't be imported in the libraries; Are there any other such best practices to be followed?

title: Runtime subscription model with Azure Functions

What is the best way of achieving this? I have complete freedom over the event infrastructure.

  • I like the look of Azure Web PubSub, but I don't see a way of adding the function's PubSub connection to a group at runtime.

Or am I misusing what Azure Functions are meant for and I should have some other infrastructure doing this instead?

declare

title: Should I make a python app thats styled with react
body:
I'm designing a web app that scans text from images or pdfs of homework assignments sent by users that sends it to chatgpt to answer the question. I'm have decent experience in python and in React, so I was wondering if I could use python send the scanned text to chatgpt and access chatgpt's response through it while using react to style the entire app. Would that approach make sense or should I just learn more javascript and get the chatgpt responses using javscript. This is for a resume project as I'm a freshman in university applying for internships.

I tried making it first in JS but i couldn't get it to work.

import Tesseract from 'tesseract.js';

const TextRecognition = () => {
  const [image, setImage] = useState(null);
  const [recognizedText, setRecognizedText] = useState('');
  const [chatResponse, setChatResponse] = useState('');
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);

  const handleImageUpload = (event) => {
    const file = event.target.files[0];
    const reader = new FileReader();

    reader.onloadend = () => {
      setImage(reader.result);
      processImage(reader.result);
    };

    if (file) {
      reader.readAsDataURL(file);
    }
  };

  const processImage = async (imageUrl) => {
    try {
      setLoading(true);

      const { data: { text } } = await Tesseract.recognize(
        imageUrl,
        'eng',
        { logger: (info) => console.log(info) }
      );

      setRecognizedText(text);
      sendToChatGPT(text);
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Error processing image:', error);
      setLoading(false);
    }
  };

  const sendToChatGPT = async (question) => {
    const apiKey = 'blah blah';
  
    try {
      const response = await fetch('https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions', {
        method: 'POST',
        headers: {
          'Content-Type': 'application/json',
          'Authorization': `Bearer ${apiKey}`,
        },
        body: JSON.stringify({
          'model': 'gpt-3.5-turbo',
          prompt: question,
          max_tokens: 100,
        }),
      });
  
      const data = await response.json();
  
      console.log('Full API Response:', data);
  
      
      if (data.choices && Array.isArray(data.choices) && data.choices.length > 0 && data.choices[0].message && data.choices[0].message.content) {
        setChatResponse(data.choices[0].message.content);
      } else {
        console.error('No valid response text found in choices.');
        setChatResponse('Error: No valid response text found.');
      }
  
      setLoading(false);
    } catch (error) {
      console.error('Error with ChatGPT API:', error);
      setLoading(false);
    }
  };
  
  

  return (
    <div className="min-h-screen w-screen flex items-center justify-center bg-gray-900 text-white">
      <div className="max-w-md w-full p-8 bg-gray-800 rounded-lg shadow-md">
        <label
          htmlFor="imageUpload"
          className="mb-4 p-2 bg-blue-500 rounded cursor-pointer text-white block"
        >
          Browse
        </label>
        <input
          type="file"
          id="imageUpload"
          onChange={handleImageUpload}
          className="hidden"
        />
        {image && (
          <div className="mb-4 max-w-full overflow-hidden rounded">
            <img src={image} alt="Uploaded" className="w-full" />
          </div>
        )}
        {recognizedText && (
          <div className="mb-4 p-4 bg-blue-500 text-white rounded">
            <p className="font-semibold">Recognized Text:</p>
            <p>{recognizedText}</p>
          </div>
        )}
        {loading && <p className="mb-4 text-blue-500">Loading ChatGPT response...</p>}
        {chatResponse && (
          <div className="p-4 bg-blue-500 text-white rounded">
            <p className="font-semibold">ChatGPT Response:</p>
            <p>{chatResponse}</p>
          </div>
        )}
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default TextRecognition;

title: Integrating AI to Optimize DevOps Processes: Implementation Challenges
body:
Hello Stack Overflow community,

I'm currently working on a project where we aim to use Artificial Intelligence to optimize our DevOps processes. Our goal is to implement AI-driven analytics to make our Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment (CI/CD) pipelines more efficient. For example, we want to use machine learning to automatically predict the likelihood of build failures and enhance quality assurance.

We've developed a prototype in Python using a simple machine learning model. Here's a snippet of our code:

import numpy as np
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score

# Load data (example data: features and labels)
# Features represent various metrics of our CI/CD pipeline
# Labels are 0 (Build successful) or 1 (Build failed)
features, labels = load_pipeline_data() 

# Splitting the data into training and testing sets
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(features, labels, test_size=0.2, random_state=42)

# Using RandomForestClassifier for prediction
clf = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=100, random_state=42)
clf.fit(X_train, y_train)

# Prediction and accuracy
predictions = clf.predict(X_test)
print(f"Accuracy: {accuracy_score(y_test, predictions)}")

However, we're facing some challenges:

  1. Which metrics from our CI/CD processes are most indicative for predicting build failures?
  2. How can we further refine our model to increase the accuracy of predictions?
  3. Are there established best practices or frameworks specifically designed for this type of application in DevOps?

Any help or insight into these topics would be greatly appreciated!

class Calculator
{

title: Converting SwiftUI App to SwiftData: Single @Model Class vs. Separate Models for Each Entity
body:
Lets say you have a SwiftUI app, like the landmarks app, that currently has single Observable class instance in charge of providing data for the whole app:

@Observable
class ModelData {
    var landmarks: [Landmark] = load("landmarkData.json")
    var hikes: [Hike] = load("hikeData.json")
    var profile = Profile.default

    var features: [Landmark] {
        landmarks.filter { $0.isFeatured }
    }

    var categories: [String: [Landmark]] {
        Dictionary(
            grouping: landmarks,
            by: { $0.category.rawValue }
        )
    }
}

It is provided to the app like this:

@main
struct LandmarksApp: App {
    @State private var modelData = ModelData()

    var body: some Scene {
        WindowGroup {
            ContentView()
                .environment(modelData)
        }
    }
}

And accessed within individual components of the app like this:

@Environment(ModelData.self) var modelData

If we were to convert this app to SwiftData, we could:

A) Model the Landmark and Hike objects separately by putting "@Model" on each one... and getting rid of the computed queries and using @Query instead. (Not sure what we would do with Profile since it is singular)... and share those two separate "model arrays" (?) with the rest of the app using the technique in this question. In this case, the ModelData class would no longer exist.

B) OR.... (this is the question)... can we just put an SwiftData "@Model" on the existing ModelData class as a whole, and share it with the entire app? I've started trying to do this, and I have got as far as

@Model
class ModelData {
    var landmarks: [Landmark]
    var hikes: [Hike]
    var profile: Profile
    
    var features: [Landmark] {
        landmarks.filter { $0.isFeatured }
    }
    var categories: [String: [Landmark]] {
        Dictionary(
            grouping: landmarks,
            by: { $0.category.rawValue }
        )
    }
    
    init(landmarks: [Landmark] = load("landmarks.json"), hikes: [Hike] = load("hikes.json"), profile:Profile = Profile.default) {
        self.landmarks = landmarks
        self.hikes = hikes
        self.profile = profile
    }
}

... and it compiles since I made everything codable... but when I start thinking about how I would edit or update landmarks my head hurts... and it seems like maybe it's never a good idea to use this "option B."

However, when I proceed with option A, I reach a point where I realize I have lost the utility functions and they will have to be scattered in the codebase.

Are these equally valid approaches?

title: What is idiomatic way to return custom error type from constructor?
body:
As far as I can see in golang sources there are no examples with error constructors except errors package itself. Basically, authors return a type that was constructed manually.

For example, we have net package with OpError custom error struct

type OpError struct {
    // Op is the operation which caused the error, such as
    // "read" or "write".
    Op string

    ...
}

func (e *OpError) Error() string {
    ...
}

and they use them by direct declaration, without any constructors

func (c *conn) SetDeadline(t time.Time) error {
    if !c.ok() {
        return syscall.EINVAL
    }
    if err := c.fd.SetDeadline(t); err != nil {
        return &OpError{Op: "set", Net: c.fd.net, Source: nil, Addr: c.fd.laddr, Err: err}
    }
    return nil
}

func (c *conn) File() (f *os.File, err error) {
    f, err = c.fd.dup()
    if err != nil {
        err = &OpError{Op: "file", Net: c.fd.net, Source: c.fd.laddr, Addr: c.fd.raddr, Err: err}
    }
    return
}

I wonder, what is idiomatic way to write custom error constructor in terms of what the type I should return? Should I return built-in interface error or instance of my custom type?

Perhaps there is our custom domain error type with some domain code and abstract details

type DomainErrorCode int

type DomainError struct {
    err error
    Code DomainErrorCode
    Details []byte
}

func (e *DomainError) Error() string {
    return e.err.Error()
}

Constructor can be

// A
func NewDomainError(err error, code DomainErrorCode, details Details) error {
    return &DomainError{err: err, Code: code, Details: details}
}

// B
func NewDomainError(err error, code DomainErrorCode, details Details) *DomainError {
    return &DomainError{err: err, Code: code, Details: details}
}

Option B is flexible and allows you to construct custom error and reach attributes like Code or Details. Option A is more encapsulated and if you need access to custom attributes you need some kind of assertation.

Then I see official guidelines of Generality

If a type exists only to implement an interface and will never have exported methods beyond that interface, there is no need to export the type itself. Exporting just the interface makes it clear the value has no interesting behavior beyond what is described in the interface. It also avoids the need to repeat the documentation on every instance of a common method.

So what is idiomatic way to write the constructor in this example? Seems like option A, because I don't have any methods besides built-in interface error. But this limits access to important custom attributes and will cost extra effort for type assertation if fields are needed. For me option B seems more reasonable

title: Command pattern design in Spring
body:
I have more or less implemented the command pattern in my Spring Boot application. I still have some doubts and would like to get second opinion on them.

I have a CommandFactory which - when given a command code - returns an instance of command object that implements Command functional interface and has a single method called execute.

Here's an example of use:

  • PersonService:
public Person addChildToPerson(Long personId, Long childId) {
    // acquire a person object from the database given an id
    Person person = (Person) commandFactory.create(GET_PERSON_BY_ID, personId).execute();
    // do the same with child
    Child child = (Child) commandFactory.create(GET_CHILD_BY_ID, childId).execute();
    return (Person) commandFactory.create(ADD_CHILD_TO_PERSON, person, child).execute();
}

Now here's the code of a AddChildToPersonCommand class that is responsible for attaching the child to the person and persisting it in the database.

  • AddChildToPersonCommand:
@RequiredArgsConstructor
public class AddChildToPersonCommand implements Command {

     // declare needed components for performing the command
     private final ChildRepository childRepository;
     private final Person person;
     private final Child child;

     @Override
     public Person execute() {
         // some logic
     }
}

Now, my doubts are mainly concerned with the "declared components" for the execution of a command. I'm unsure whether it's a better practice to operate on the actual objects that have been already retrieved using other commands (in the example: GetPersonByIdCommand & GetChildByIdCommand) or to just give the AddChildToPersonCommand the IDs and let it take care of the rest.

On the one hand, it seems a better approach to operate on the objects as it decreases the responsibilites of AddChildToPersonCommand.

On the other hand, though, the PersonService's methods may end up really big when the logic to-be-performed is not as trivial as in this example.

What do you think?

title: Angular what's the best way to switch states in html display
body:
Having to decide on two different approaches for dealing with component view between loading. By "best way" I'm talking about performance, UI less blinking (less DOM renderizations), whatever you know.

Option 1: Use loading variable to hide content while not ready

// .scss
<styles>
  .loading {
    visibility: hidden;
  }
</styles>

// .ts
this.loading = false;
this.service.getLetters().then(array => {
  this.loading = array.length === 0;
})

// .html
<div [ngClass]="{ 'loading': loading}">
  <div *ngFor="let letter in letters">
    {{letter}}
  </div>
  <div *ngIf="letters.length === 0">
    No letters to be shown
  </div>
</div>

Option 2: Using promises to switch between html

// .ts
noLetters: Promise<boolean>;
lettersPromise: Promise<Array>;
letters: Array;

this.lettersPromise = this.service.getLetters();
this.noLetters = this.lettersPromise.then(letters => letters.length === 0);

// .html
<div *ngIf="(noLetters | async) === false">
  <div *ngfor="let letter in letters">
    {{letter}}
  </div>
</div>
<div *ngIf="(noLetters | async)">
  No letters to be shown
</div>

Option 2 seems more powerfull to me in terms it can be more flexible ? And I think the UI does blinks less..

Can I get an opinion on this ?

title: DELETING 100 mil rows from an ORACLE database. The best approach?
body:
we have a huge db cleanup action coming in and there's going to be around 100 mil rows deleted in total. There are 40 tables to delete data from. Here are my ideas and I'm open to suggestions

#1 approach

Bulk collect and then delete while logging which rows are deleted. Committing every 100 rows

Example->

--define record and needed variables

commit_counter NUMBER := 0;
COMMIT_LIMIT CONSTANT NUMBER := 100; 
v_total_deleted_services NUMBER := 0;
TYPE t_record_entity_test IS RECORD (
    ENTITY_ID NUMBER,
    SOURCE VARCHAR2(100),
    SOURCE_ID VARCHAR2(100),
    MESSAGE_ID VARCHAR2(100),
    STATUS VARCHAR2(200)
);

 TYPE t_record_entity_tests IS TABLE OF t_record_entity_test INDEX BY PLS_INTEGER;
 v_records_test t_record_entity_tests;

//Make cursor
 CURSOR c_services IS
        SELECT --all the data needed--

  OPEN c_services;
    LOOP
        FETCH c_services BULK COLLECT INTO v_records_test LIMIT 10000; 
        EXIT WHEN v_records_test.COUNT = 0;

   FORALL i IN 1..v_records_test.COUNT
            INSERT INTO DELETE_LOG_TEST(SOURCE, SOURCE_ID, status, log_date)
            VALUES (v_records_test(i).SOURCE, v_records_test(i).SOURCE_ID, 'Service DELETED,' || ' Status: ' ||v_records_test(i).status , SYSDATE);

   FORALL i IN 1..v_records_test.COUNT
            DELETE FROM SERVICE WHERE ENTITY_ID = v_records_test(i).ENTITY_ID;
            v_total_deleted_services := v_total_deleted_services + SQL%ROWCOUNT;

        commit_counter := commit_counter + v_records_test.COUNT;

       IF commit_counter >= COMMIT_LIMIT THEN
            COMMIT;
            commit_counter := 0; 
        END IF;



   end loop;
close c_services;
commit;
--log number of deleted rows

#2 approach

Bulk collect and log which rows are being deleted. Delete all at once and then commit at the end. Don't know if it's ok since there could be 10 mil rows deleted in one of these actions

--define record and needed variables

v_total_deleted_services NUMBER := 0;
TYPE t_record_entity_test IS RECORD (
    ENTITY_ID NUMBER,
    SOURCE VARCHAR2(100),
    SOURCE_ID VARCHAR2(100),
    MESSAGE_ID VARCHAR2(100),
    STATUS VARCHAR2(200)
);

 TYPE t_record_entity_tests IS TABLE OF t_record_entity_test INDEX BY PLS_INTEGER;
 v_records_test t_record_entity_tests;

//Make cursor
 CURSOR c_services IS
        SELECT --all the data needed--

  OPEN c_services;
    LOOP
        FETCH c_services BULK COLLECT INTO v_records_test LIMIT 10000; 
        EXIT WHEN v_records_test.COUNT = 0;

   FORALL i IN 1..v_records_test.COUNT
            INSERT INTO DELETE_LOG_TEST(SOURCE, SOURCE_ID, status, log_date)
            VALUES (v_records_test(i).SOURCE, v_records_test(i).SOURCE_ID, 'Service DELETED,' || ' Status: ' ||v_records_test(i).status , SYSDATE);
    end loop;
close c_services;

            DELETE FROM SERVICE WHERE ENTITY_ID = --select entity_id of data needed to be deleted that is the same data that's in the cursor;
    
            v_total_deleted_services := v_total_deleted_services + SQL%ROWCOUNT;



   
commit;
--log number of deleted rows

What's a better approach and is there's a third which would be better than these 2?

title: Distance measure between topic distributions accounting for correlation between topics
body:
I have trained a topic model on a collection of newspaper articles that I manually identified to serve as a benchmark. Let's assume the topic model identifies three topics, like politics, economics, and sports. Next, I evaluate the model on a different set of newspaper articles. Now, for all articles in the 'training' and 'evaluation' sets, I have a distribution across the three identified topics.

Now, I want to compute a similarity measure between all articles in the training and all articles in the evaluation sets. However, to my understanding, the most commonly used measures, like cosine similarity, do not account for the correlation between topics. For example, politics and economics are closer substitutes than politics and sports. My idea would be to compute a correlation matrix from the article topic distribution in the training data to calculate a weighted distance measure.

My first question is if it makes sense to account for this correlation. Second, has anyone seen such a measure?

I already computed the correlation matrix and used the Mahalanobis distance but I have not found a reference.

title: Best Practices for retrieving data in MVC: Concerns about Using POST for Retrieval and Token Handling
body:
I'm currently working on a MVC app. I've implemented a route using a POST method to retrieve information and navigate to the corresponding page, and I have some concerns about the design practices I'm using. This is the route:

app.post('/metrics/service/:serviceId', async (req, res) => {
        target = req.query.target;
        errors = [];
        if (!target) {
            res.render('metrics', {error: 'Please select a target to get the metrics from'});

I have several concerns regarding this implementation:

If I change the method to GET I'm concerned about security by having tokens in the URL. What would be a more secure approach? Is it better to pass tokens via headers or any other recommended method?

  • Combination of URL parameters and body data: Currently, I'm using a combination of URL parameters (serviceId), query parameters (target) and the token from the request body. Is this approach acceptable, or should I modify it to maintain a more consistent approach?

title: Whats the suitable way of handling events in signal processing? (ImGui IDE)
body:
I'm looking to implement a functionality that handles a change of input i.e. a button clicked in a GUI, or in my case, a signal received by an udp-socket. I want the event to be handled in a way, that an object Foo fooReceived, received in class Receiver, is passed to a member function handlerFunc(Foo fooReceived) of another class Handler.

So far I came up with two approaches:

  1. Using signal-slot procedure: Whenever an event occurs, a signal is emitted, which evokes the slot handlerFunc(Foo fooReceived), which is a public member function of Receiver. I used this approach while developing GTKMM GUIs. A basic example of the library sigc++ can be found here.

  2. Using a callback procedure with function objects:

#include <functional>
#include <iostream>

struct Foo {
    int data;
};

// Handler class with a member function to handle the received data
class Handler {
public:
    void handlerFunc(const Foo& fooReceived) {
        //handle fooReceived
    }
};

// Receiver class with a callback mechanism
class Receiver {
public:
    // Define a callback type using std::function
    using CallbackType = std::function<void(const Foo&)>;

    // Set the callback function
    void setCallback(const CallbackType& callback) {
        callback_ = callback;
    }

    // Simulate receiving data and trigger the callback
    void receiveData(const Foo& foo) {
        if (callback_) {
            callback_(foo);
        }
    }

private:
    // Callback function to be triggered when data is received
    CallbackType callback_;
};

int main() {
    Handler handler;
    Receiver receiver;

    // Set the callback function in the Receiver
    receiver.setCallback(std::bind(&Handler::handlerFunc, &handler, std::placeholders::_1));

    // Simulate receiving data in the Receiver
    Foo receivedFoo{42};
    receiver.receiveData(receivedFoo);

    return 0;
}

Notice that within the second approach, its necessairy to have a Handler instance, so the callback can be set. Consiquently I would have to set a member instance of Handler in the Receiver class which is not the case in the signal slot approach.

Since I'm looking to handle the data by plotting them in a GUI (ImGui) that is not Gtk, I feel like sigc++ should not be used. Will setting a member instance of Handlercause any problems? What are potential risks with this approach?

title: Should unit tests include validation?
body:
Say I have an object called File which exposes three methods: WriteRecord, Iterate, and GetSize. The contract for WriteRecord is that it returns false if the input would cause the File to exceed 16kb. Otherwise, it returns true and stores the record in the file. However, if the File is empty, but the Record is larger than 16kb, we accept the record anyway (otherwise it would never get written).

Say I have a test for WriteRecord where the record is 16.1kb. In this test, we call WriteRecord and validate that it returned true. Should we also validate that GetSize returns 16.1kb, to make sure WriteRecord actually stored this record? And should we also validate that Iterate returns this record? Or should we have three separate tests for the same 16.1kb case?

title: What Are the Long-Term Cost and Implementation Pros and Cons of SFTPGo on GCE vs GKE?
body:
I am evaluating deployment options for SFTPGo and would like to understand the pros and cons, with a particular focus on long-term cost-effectiveness and the time required for implementation. Cloud Run is not a viable option due to its lack of FTP support, so I am considering either a VM or Kubernetes.

The application will use SFTPGo to connect to GCE buckets, primarily serving PDFs and image files. It is expected to handle a few thousand transactions daily.

Below are some of my considerations for both GCE and Kubernetes (GKE). I welcome your opinions and points of disagreement, as my view is biased towards Kubernetes.

GCE:

  • Slightly cheaper in terms of running costs, though database expenses, such as those for PostgreSQL, will be comparable.
  • Implementing GitOps might be time-consuming, particularly for creating immutable images with Packer, as I have not found any ready-made solutions online.
  • Potentially more challenging to integrate with a database and Single Sign-On.
  • Less flexibility in scaling; restarts take longer.
  • A noticeable lack of pre-built solutions, potentially leading to increased maintenance overhead.

GKE:

  • Marginally more expensive, with database costs like PostgreSQL being similar to those in GCE.
  • A community-supported Helm chart is available, offering quick installation. It provides multiple configurations and examples for database connections, among other features.
  • Highly scalable; many changes can be made without the need for restarts, and restarts, when necessary, are quick.
  • Benefits from pre-configured integration and strong community support.
  • Given the recent concerns with HashiCorp and Terraform, there is uncertainty about their future products. In contrast, Kubernetes is open-source and widely adopted.

I am particularly interested in insights regarding long-term cost efficiency and operational management. Thank you in advance for your input.
